Articles.Content:
I am attempting to build a modular SSTO. The idea is to build a brick-like thing that can get to space and to make it dockable from all directions -> I can slap some cargo between them or create bigger clusters of SSTO, where each part can deorbit and land one by one after the cargo is delivered.

Here is a pic of the craft, still in early design stages but a test flight got it to orbit:

Now when I try to dock two of these together side by side, aircraft controls act really weird. When attempting to roll, the two craft seem to work against each other -> I guess the controls are still locked by each craft and not globally assigned after docking.

Pitch and yaw worked, but I guess they will be trouble when I dock one of these after another or create a 2x2 block.

Any ideas on how to make this work? I guess I could go through all control surfaces and invert them one by one but that is just silly. Maybe the whole idea was...

edit: the control surfaces worked well, my design did not

Edited February 26, 2014 by LordFjord

When you dock two ships together they become one ship. What you're describing is strange, but I can remember there is sometimes a problem with some control parts, e.g. control surfaces normally act differently ahead and behind CoM, but as the CoM passes the part (e.g. as fuel is used up), the surface often keep acting the same way it was, in the end doing the opposite than what it should.

So maybe try to switch to Space Center or some other ship after you dock, then switch back and it might fix itself.

The problem your having may be caused by the game getting confused as to where control is coming from. I would suggest to try attaching a probe pod closer to where the center of mass shifts to when two are docked together, then after docking right click it and select to "control form here". This may solve your problem.

Good Luck!
Thanks for the ideas, I'll test them and post some results (and epic fails).

Well, I did some tests, with both switching craft, quicksave/reload didnt change much and the parts behaved as they should on the runway.

I blame my bad design.

None of the docked vessels made it far. Most crashed soon after taking off. Rolling had an effect, but usually into the wrong direction and with a huge drop in pitch as well. It was uncontrollable, with or without SAS.

I had some good laughs though with these tests, here are some pics for the lulz...

I marked this question as solved, the control surfaces indeed did move correctly. Directly after docking, after switching craft, quicksave/load, worked all the same.
